Award.AwardTitle: American Meteorological Society Summer Policy Colloquium 2018-2020; Washington, DC
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to build knowledge, experience and leadership capacity in the intersection of science and policy. The American Meteorological Society (AMS) will conduct an annual Summer Policy Colloquium in Washington DC that will enable interactions with agency leaders, policy makers and government leaders in the legislative and executive branches. The unique set of instructors in the Colloquium typically has interdisciplinary backgrounds in science, policy, and law. The attendees are provided instruction to allow development of skills and techniques for communicating science to policymakers and the public in ways that encourage information sharing and collaboration. Additionally, through instruction, examples, and exercises, attendees learn the legislative process and the roles of science information in support of policy. As a result, the national dialogue among scientists, policymakers, and the public will become more efficient, clear, and solution-oriented. This benefits support of national policy with respect to increased understanding and management of natural resources critical to food, water, energy, resilience to hazards, and environmental protection.

AMS will use funds provided by NSF to support the attendance of early career scientists as well as faculty members from Historically Black Colleges and Universities, and Minority Serving Institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The American Meteorological Society (AMS) Summer Policy Colloquium introduces early-career scientists to the federal science policy framework that both funds basic R&D in the geosciences and at the same time constitutes an important and unique demand for products from that R&D. For nearly two decades the Colloquium has brought some 20-40 scientists/year to Washington, DC, for an intensive ten days and nights of conversation with a comparable number of policymakers in the legislative and executive branches of government as well as stakeholders from the corporate world, academia, and NGO?s. In 2020, the covid-19 pandemic made it necessary to conduct the Colloquium virtually. This posed new challenges but also surfaced some new strengths that point to opportunities for enhancing the Colloquium?s impact going forward.

More than 600 scientists have gone through the program to date. The Colloquium encourages and equips scientists to be as disciplined in their approach to the policy process as they are to their research. The program helps them play their appropriate role: informing policy and identifying and exploring options, without advocating for particular policy positions. The Colloquium experience has inspired many participants to seek and take on temporary and permanent staff employment across the Congress, as well as assume leadership positions in federal laboratories and agencies. One has even served as the president's science advisor.

At the same time, Colloquium encounters introduce members of Congress and staffers to young scientists. Over time, the continuing engagement has fostered the trust across these disparate communities that is needed for mitigation of and adaptation to climate change, building community and national resilience to hazards, maintaining air- and water quality, and other national priorities.

By these means, the Colloquium accelerates and increases the societal benefit from investments in the geosciences, not just nationally but globally.
